instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails there, but no power
threads.message:
Hi there, I don't get these boards a lot.
I'm hoping this isn't a dead cpu, but just had to ask if there are any checks I can do before sending this back .


So it's a 00045 board that has no liquid or drop damage but suddenly stopped working.
When connected to 87W charger I get 20v in @ 0,4/0,5 amps (no battery connected.)
All rails present at correct voltages, up to cpuvcore at a stable 1.7V.
when I connect a usb bootable, there is only a stable light, no flashing/loading activity.

does this already sound like a dead cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails there, but no power
threads.message:
If is not CPU yet, it will die soon.
You can try new BIOS, but I don't recommend to waste time on it.
These boards can come back with dead CPU after solving a power issue.
Client will claim warranty, even if is not related issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails there, but no power
threads.message: Alright, thanks for the advice.. i guess i'm going to not waste time on this then!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails there, but no power
